how to put a pin on line in the code

To put a pin (or bookmark) on a specific line in the code, you can use the source code editor's built-in bookmark functionality. Most modern code editors and IDEs (Integrated Development Environments) provide this feature to help developers quickly navigate and mark important lines or sections of code.
Here are the steps to put a pin or bookmark on a line in the code:
1. **IntelliJ IDEA / Android Studio**: - Navigate to the line of code where you want to put a bookmark. - Press `F11` on Windows/Linux or `Command + F3` on macOS, or right-click on the line and select `Toggle Bookmark`. - A blue bookmark icon will appear in the gutter (left margin) of the editor.
2. **Visual Studio Code**: - Navigate to the line of code where you want to put a bookmark. - Press `Ctrl + Alt + K` on Windows/Linux or `Command + Option + K` on macOS, or click on the gutter (left margin) next to the line. - A blue bookmark icon will appear in the gutter.
3. **Sublime Text**: - Navigate to the line of code where you want to put a bookmark. - Press `Ctrl + F2` on Windows/Linux or `Command + F2` on macOS. - A bookmark icon will appear in the gutter (left margin) of the editor.
4. **Atom**: - Navigate to the line of code where you want to put a bookmark. - Press `Ctrl + F2` on Windows/Linux or `Command + F2` on macOS. - A bookmark icon will appear in the gutter (left margin) of the editor.
5. **Vim**: - Navigate to the line of code where you want to put a bookmark. - Press `m` followed by a letter (e.g., `ma` to set a bookmark named `a`). - To navigate to the bookmarked line, press `'` followed by the letter you used (e.g., `'a` to go to the bookmark named `a`).
Once you've set a bookmark or pin on a line, you can quickly navigate back to that line using the editor's bookmark navigation features. Most editors provide a way to list all bookmarks and jump between them.
Bookmarks are useful for marking important lines of code, such as entry points, critical sections, or places where you need to revisit or make changes later. They can help you stay organized and efficient when working with large codebases.
